Problem:
Consider a system where the state vector \\( x \\) evolves in time according to the partial differential equation \\( \\frac{\\partial x}{\\partial t} = Lx \\), where L is a linear differential operator. We study the effect of applying a Fourier transform \\( F \\) to the initial state \\( x_0 \\) and then letting this transformed state evolve under \\( \\frac{\\partial x}{\\partial t} = Lx \\).

If a Fourier transform \\( F(x) \\) is applied to an initial state \\( x_0 \\) and it then evolves according to \\( \\frac{\\partial x}{\\partial t} = Lx \\) without any further intervention, will \\( x(t) \\) at a later time t = T be the same as if \\( x_0 \\) had evolved directly under the same differential equation?
Explanation: The Fourier transform dramatically alters the frequency components of \\( x_0 \\), which means the system’s evolution under \\( L \\) will propagate differently compared to the untransformed state. This results in a different state at time T because the operational dynamics on the transformed frequencies can lead to disparate outcomes.
